Such a great game! Clever, engaging, well designed maps and super zombies to cross your path. No Mercy is perfect. Death Toll is scary and funny (DING DONG! DINNER'S SERVED!). Dead Air is the map I enjoy playing the most. The Harvest is epic. Find a group of friends and play this, if you haven't. You'll have a blast.

Left 4 Dead will go down (if it already hasn't) as one of the all-time classics, right up there with Half-Life 1 & 2, Halo: CE, DOOM, and all the other great titles. Sure, Left 4 Dead 2 is superior in every way (except for the horror atmosphere), but that game wouldn't exist without this one.

And yeah, you can buy L4D2 and get all the original L4D campaigns bundled with it, but it's not entirely the same experience. Valve took the opportunity to tweak and adjust how certain parts of the original campaigns played when they ported them to L4D2. The terrain of the "No Mercy" finale was changed significantly, the tight-roping/ledge-hopping you could do to skip a small chunk of the "Dead Air" opening was taken out, and so many more little things. Some of them may have been exploits that weaseled their way through play-testing, but they do give the game a little extra character.

L4D was a big deal when it came out. The year 2008 was the height of the Valve Golden Age; Half-Life 2: Episode 2 had come out the year before, along with Team Fortress 2, and a rinky-dink puzzle game called Portal. Valve Software was the untouchable, undisputed king of the video game world, and they showed no signs of slowing down or stopping.

I was 12 when this game came out, and I can still remember to this day the huge marketing campaign Valve orchestrated for what was then a new game, and the genre it pioneered. That 30-second TV-spot featuring "Train to Miami" by Steel Pole Bath Tub (https://youtu.be/YnuYnzXUuGY) was the first commercial I remember seeing for a video game on TV, and those 30 seconds made one helluva impression on me. While 12-year old me had no business playing this game in 2008, I got my hands on it nonetheless and sunk hundreds of hours into it on my old Xbox 360. It was, and still is, a masterpiece.

Pardon me for waxing nostalgic, but Left 4 Dead will forever hold a special place in my heart.

This is an absolute classic. Yes, Left 4 Dead 2 has more features in it, but this game still has its own charm as well as great historical value with it being one of the definitive co-op shooters that many games would later be influenced by, like Payday or Earthfall.
